ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank Prof Karen O’ Brien for her expertise and guidance during the project. The Climate Beliefs project, exploring the relationship between belief systems and climate change, was conducted as part of the South Africa–Norway Research Co-operation on Climate Change, the Environment and Clean Energy (SANCOOP) bilateral agreement between South Africa and Norway.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest with regard to the writing of this article.

sec.title: Authors’ contributions
sec.p: S.S. was the researcher. J-V.D. was the Q-methodological and statistical analyst. D.v.N. was the director of the African Center for Disaster Studies (ACDS) and the co-supervisor. R.A.L. was the principal investigator (PI) and the South African team leader on the Climate Beliefs Project (project number: 234277, unique grant number: 91322), exploring the hypothesis that more flexible belief systems contribute to an increased capacity to adapt to climate change. R.A.L. was the supervisor for this study.

sec.title: Funding information
sec.p: The research was funded by the National Research Foundation (NRF) of South Africa and the Research Council of Norway.
